channel.title: School network exploting
channel.description:
I'm not experienced in the field of network exploiting, and I want to know if it is possible to "hack" or "crack" (As many people misinterpret the real meaning of the words.) into files on the network you're on, but do not have access to.
All of my school's computers are linked together on multiple server's spread across the campus.
[b]Information that might help:[/b](These are only guesses as I am not completely sure.)
I infer that they have an "access" system that allows different users to have different accesses, such as students(me) have student access, teachers have teacher access, then there is the admin access that has full access.
Each user has it's own folder on the server that is accessible by that user only, or someone that has higher accesses. (Teachers can view the students server-sided folder but can't view other teacher's folders. Students can look at there server-sided folder only.)
I checked the location of my server-sided folder and it was (\\schoolDis\students\4300621\My documents)
I got into "schoolDis" but as I was looking trough all the files I could not find the "students" folder, I did have hidden folders enabled to show up.. So they are not completely stupid.
They log in to a user using the user login in on windows vista/XP after boot up and they view the files by the normal windows explorer.(The file viewer not the web browser -.-) Windows-KEY+E
[b]Now to my question:[/b] How would I at least view the "students" folder in this situation, from my user account witch I think has student access.
Disclaimer: I only wan't this information for learning purposes, I will not carry these actions out.

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Budda, post:10, topic:301311”]All of you are retarded.

If you go into explorer, go tools, map network drive, choose a letter, then in the folder field put in that server you had (\schoolDis\students) then click finish, it will add a new drive pointing at the students folder. If you have access to one of the folders inside there, i.e. your own, you should be able to open this new drive. Once in there, there will most likely be all the folders for the students, and I’m pretty sure they will be restricted.

Alternatively, befriend one of the network admins, and get him to show you how the network works.[/quote]

The first statement is possible, although the second one is pretty much improbable since there is only 2 network admins to my knowledge, and only one stays on campus. His name is Tom and the only reason I know this is because I had to go into his office and prove to the stupid school that I wasn’t impersonating the assistant principle… Dumbasses. >.>

Read full topic

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @Budda Budda
item.description:
@Budda wrote:

All of you are retarded.

If you go into explorer, go tools, map network drive, choose a letter, then in the folder field put in that server you had (\schoolDis\students) then click finish, it will add a new drive pointing at the students folder. If you have access to one of the folders inside there, i.e. your own, you should be able to open this new drive. Once in there, there will most likely be all the folders for the students, and I’m pretty sure they will be restricted.

Alternatively, befriend one of the network admins, and get him to show you how the network works.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Telenim Telenim
item.description:
@Telenim wrote:

[quote=“Javafire, post:7, topic:301311”]just try putting a hidden keylogger in one of the school computers, works for me ;)[/quote]Too bad it won’t work

Read full topic

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Telenim, post:6, topic:301311”]I’m not sure if it would be the same, but for us we could just simply type

C:(the login user:)Jven8\Documents\

in the address bar[/quote]

I tried that and it said something about the directory not existing.

Read full topic

@Telenim wrote:

I’m not sure if it would be the same, but for us we could just simply type

in the address bar

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

r0ckstar96:

The C:/ drive usually should contain everything, I noticed i was on the K:/ drive when I logged in and I was curious so I went to the C:/ drive and there was everything the school had, on my account! I didn’t do anything because they log everything we do and I’m not really a troublemaker.

It didn’t specify which drive it was on. Only ("\") there the drive is suppose to be.

Read full topic

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @r0ckstar96 r0ckstar96
item.description:

The C:/ drive usually should contain everything, I noticed i was on the K:/ drive when I logged in and I was curious so I went to the C:/ drive and there was everything the school had, on my account! I didn’t do anything because they log everything we do and I’m not really a troublemaker.

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Explisionist, post:2, topic:301311”]You need to crack his/her network…

My school recently upgraded their system, because last year people deleted his website blocks.

But ours is like s:{student’s name like “ghunt”}/My Files/
the s is a new hard drive he added, which is easily obtained by typing administrator backwards, idk why its that but last year it worked.
Also, find out what login client he/she uses, that will provide us with a better reference in helping you.[/quote]

They log in to a user using the user login in on windows vista/XP after boot up and they view the files by the normal windows explorer.(The file viewer not the web browser -.-) Windows-KEY+E

Read full topic

item.title: School network exploting
item.dc:creator: @Explisionist Explisionist
item.description:
@Explisionist wrote:

You need to crack his/her network…

My school recently upgraded their system, because last year people deleted his website blocks.

But ours is like s:{student’s name like “ghunt”}/My Files/
the s is a new hard drive he added, which is easily obtained by typing administrator backwards, idk why its that but last year it worked.
Also, find out what login client he/she uses, that will provide us with a better reference in helping you.

Read full topic
